Context:
The text provides information about a blockchain program offered by George Brown College. Here are the key facts extracted from the text:

- The program is developed using blockchain technology and offers a holistic understanding of the domain.
- It consists of approximately 20 hours per week of evening classes, spread over a 26-week period.
- Students will learn skills such as smart contracts, design patterns for blockchain, decentralized system development, full stack development & integration, and blockchain architecture.
- In the last semester, students have the option to undertake a co-op work placement or work-integrated project.
- Technology requirements include a personal computer with at least 8 GB RAM, a Quad-core i5/i7 processor, ability to run Ubuntu 20.04, and a webcam.
- Students complete a Work Integrated Project in semester 3 or are eligible for co-op.
- Graduates can apply for positions such as blockchain engineer, blockchain developer, blockchain architect, smart contract developer, dApp developer, blockchain solution analyst, and blockchain consultant.
- Industry partners include ConsenSys and ChainSafe Systems.
- Students engage in increasingly independent case studies during the three-semester program.

Therefore, the extracted information is:

[The text describes a blockchain program offered by George Brown College that consists of approximately 20 hours per week of evening classes over a 26-week period. Students will learn skills such as smart contracts, design patterns for blockchain, decentralized system development, full stack development & integration, and blockchain architecture. In the last semester, students have the option to undertake a co-op work placement or work-integrated project. Technology requirements include a personal computer with at least 8 GB RAM, a Quad-core i5/i7 processor, ability to run Ubuntu 20.04, and a webcam. Graduates can apply for positions such as blockchain engineer, blockchain developer, blockchain architect, smart contract developer, dApp developer, blockchain solution analyst, and blockchain consultant. Industry partners include ConsenSys and ChainSafe Systems. Students engage in increasingly independent case studies during the three-semester program.]

Context:
The text provides information about the courses offered in a blockchain program at the college during Semesters 1, 2, and 3. Here's an extracted summary of the factual data from the text:

Semester 1:
- Courses: BCDV 4001 (Blockchain Foundations), BCDV 4010 (Smart Contract Development Essentials), BCDV 4021 (Front-end Web Development), BCDV 4022 (Back-end Web Development), BCDV 4023 (Full Stack Blockchain Integration - I), BCDV4028 (Advanced Smart Contract Development), BCDV4029 (Decentralized Governance Framework), BCDV4030 (Blockchain Business Models), BCDV4031 (DeFi Fundamentals)
- Prerequisites: N/A (Not mentioned in the text)

Semester 2:
- Courses: BCDV 4019 (Advanced Blockchain Topics), BC DV 4025 (Enterprise Blockchain Development), BC DV 4026 (Blockchain Platforms), BC DV 4027 (Capstone Project), BC DV 4032 (Building Scalable Blockchain Apps), BC DV 4033 (DevOps and Blockchain Administration), BC DV 4034 (Full Stack Blockchain Integration - II), BC DV 4023 (COMP 4064)
- Prerequisites: BCDV 4019 requires no prerequisites. Other courses have prerequisites that are not mentioned in the text.

Semester 3:
- Courses: BC DV 4015 (Work-Integrated Project), TCOP 4007 (Co-op Work Placement)
- Prerequisites: N/A (Not mentioned in the text)

Program Learning Outcomes:
- The graduate will be able to communicate essential concepts related to blockchain technology and its industry applications.
- The graduate will be able to implement best security practices for blockchain solutions.
- The graduate will be able to design cryptoeconomic models to solve business problems.
- The graduate will be able to design the architecture of decentralized applications and systems.
- The graduate will be able to develop decentralized applications leveraging blockchain technology.
- The graduate will be able to explain the legal implications, regulations and industry standards that are relevant to blockchain technology.
- The graduate will be able to apply IT project management principles and best practices.
- The graduate will contribute to the field and blockchain community through various open-source projects, partnerships and community involvement.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $8,516.00
- International Tuition: $18,443.00

Additional Costs:
- Amounts listed are the estimated total of tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters starting in Fall 2023. Fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2024 and later dates. This fee does not include books which are to be purchased separately.

No specific information about the college name or location was provided in the text.

Context:
The text provides information about the fees and admission requirements for programs starting in Fall 2024 at George Brown College's School of Computer Technology. The estimated tuition, materials, student service, and ancillary fees for the first two semesters are listed, but they are subject to change without notice. International students should refer to specific pages on the website for more information about fees and admission requirements.

The text also mentions that applicants need a two- or three-year diploma or bachelor's degree in information technology, computer science, or a related field, and they must meet English language proficiency requirements. Course exemptions may be granted based on college or university credits.

Applicants should apply through Ontario Colleges for domestic admissions and the George Brown College Online Application System for international admissions. Contact the School of Computer Technology at 416-415-5000, ext. 4287 or computertechnology@georgebrown.ca with any inquiries. The office hours are Monday – Friday: 9 a.m. – 4 p.m.

No specific program name is mentioned in the text.
